docs.lead_paragraph: Ending insurance discrimination against the sick was a central goal of the nation's health care overhaul, but leading patient groups say that promise is being undermined by new barriers from insurers.

headline.main: Groups Claim Insurance Discrimination in New Forms
headline.print_headline: Groups Claim Insurance Discrimination in New Forms

docs.snippet: Ending insurance discrimination against the sick was a central goal of the nation's health care overhaul, but leading patient groups say that promise is being undermined by new barriers from insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing the prospect of impossibly long waiting lists for organs, some patients have turned to an underground trade that pairs them with people willing to sell an organ.

headline.main: Transplant Brokers in Israel Lure Desperate Kidney Patients to Costa Rica

docs.abstract: New York Times analysis of major organ trafficking cases since 2000 suggests that Israeli organ brokers have played disproportionate role in global organ trade; documents show Israeli brokers Avigad Sandler, Boris Volfman and Yaacov Dayan are among the central operators in Israel's underground kidney market, and have pocketed enormous sums for arranging overseas transplants for patients who are paired with foreign donors, many from impoverished countries.
docs.snippet: Facing the prospect of impossibly long waiting lists for organs, some patients have turned to an underground trade that pairs them with people willing to sell an organ.

byline.contributor: Irit Pazner Garshowitz contributed reporting from Jerusalem, and Mónica Quesada Cordero from San José, Costa Rica.

docs.lead_paragraph: The allure of the life fades as fund-raising and medical calls intrude on the primary duty: Putting water on fire.
docs.abstract: News analysis; number of volunteer firefighters in the United States has dropped by around 11 percent since the mid-1980s, while number of career firefighters has grown by more than 50 percent; decline is due in part to diminishing allure of volunteer firefighting,since fund-raising takes up almost half the time volunteers are on duty; officials are looking to attract new volunteers, as they save $139.8 billion annually for local governments.
docs.snippet: The allure of the life fades as fund-raising and medical calls intrude on the primary duty: Putting water on fire.

byline.original: By ANDREW BROWN and IAN URBINA

docs.lead_paragraph: Starting in January, Medicare will pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for patients with two or more chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes and depression.

headline.main: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients
headline.print_headline: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients

docs.abstract: Obama administration is planning to pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for Medicare beneficiaries with two or more chronic conditions; major policy change comes amid growing evidence that patients with chronic illnesses suffer from disjointed, fragmented care; new initiative will adopt techniques devised by health maintenance organizations.
docs.snippet: Starting in January, Medicare will pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for patients with two or more chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes and depression.

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers are their own bosses in the so-called sharing economy, but that flexibility also brings much uncertainty — and few of the protections of full-time work.

headline.main: In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty

docs.abstract: Self-employed workers in the so-called sharing economy, built around companies like Uber, Taskrabbit and Airbnb, have flexibility but enjoy few of the protections of full-time work; online marketplace for such services is growing, but those who work in it often go without health insurance, payroll deductions for Social Security and unemployment benefits.
docs.snippet: Workers are their own bosses in the so-called sharing economy, but that flexibility also brings much uncertainty — and few of the protections of full-time work.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study finds that people who are good at planning their financial future are more likely to take steps to improve their physical health.

headline.main: Your 401(k) Is Healthy. So Maybe You Are, Too.
headline.print_headline: Your 401(k) Is Healthy. So Maybe You Are, Too.

docs.abstract: Matt Richtel Applied Sciences column examines study in journal Psychological Science finding that people who save for retirement are more likely to take steps to improve their physical health; holds that study complements body of research showing that some people are more predisposed than others to invest in the future.
docs.snippet: A study finds that people who are good at planning their financial future are more likely to take steps to improve their physical health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma, who run the festival, where two attendees died in drug-related episodes last year, are in the middle of a discussion within the world of electronic dance music about how to stem the tide of drugs.

headline.main: A Year After Drug Deaths, the Electric Zoo Music Festival Tries Again

docs.abstract: Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma, couple who run Electric Zoo, New York's largest dance music festival, are in midst of conversation about how to stem tide of drugs following spate of drug-related deaths at their own and other festivals; Bindra and de Palma have made some changes to how they run Electric Zoo.
docs.snippet: Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma, who run the festival, where two attendees died in drug-related episodes last year, are in the middle of a discussion within the world of electronic dance music about how to stem the tide of drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Diamond Dallas Page, a former W.W.E. wrestler, created a new form of healing for broken-down macho guys like himself.
docs.abstract: Alex French article describes how former World Wrestling Entertainment wrestler Diamond Dallas Page has created new form of yoga that uses WWE-like blend of manliness and goofiness and has helped older wrestlers rehabilitate their injuries.
docs.snippet: Diamond Dallas Page, a former W.W.E. wrestler, created a new form of healing for broken-down macho guys like himself.

docs.lead_paragraph: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.

headline.main: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop
headline.print_headline: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop

docs.abstract: Obama administration's declared war on health care fraud is returning only meager results, despite escalation, recovering about $4.3 billion of an estimated $60 billion in 2013; interviews reveal that sprawling effort relies on an array of poorly-managed outside contractors, rife with conflicts of interest and vulnerable to political influence.
docs.snippet: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.

keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and ERIC LICHTBLAU

docs.lead_paragraph: One year after record-setting floods devastated Colorado, the disaster has taken center stage in the state's contentious U.S. Senate race.

headline.main: Battle Over Flood Aid Roils Colorado Senate Race
headline.print_headline: Battle Over Flood Aid Roils Colorado Senate Race

docs.snippet: One year after record-setting floods devastated Colorado, the disaster has taken center stage in the state's contentious U.S. Senate race.
